Last year British runner Mo Farah followed in the footsteps of home-grown Czech talent Emil Zátopek and became only the seventh person ever to win in the 5,000 and 10,000 metres. So what can Mo achieve at this year’s World Championships in Moscow? What we do know is that we’ll be raising a glass whatever the outcome. Timeline Photos

How did Vaclav Berka become our Brewmaster? Here he explains to Huffington Post

"When I received training from my previous predecessors, they all told me, 'Don't make changes in the recipe, the ingredients or the process. Be sure the taste of the beer is the same as before.' This is very important, because this is how we reproduce the same Pilsner Urquell that was brewed in the 19th century.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lan-anh-vu/how-i-got-there-vaclav-be_b_9162964.html How I Got There: Vaclav Berka Vaclav Berka is the senior trade brewmaster and chairman of the supervisory board of Pilsner Urquell. One of the most famous beers in the world, Pilsner Urquell, is brewed in Pilsner in the Czec...
It’s nearly Christmas so here’s a message from Brewmaster Vaclav Berka #NaZdravi Merry Christmas from Brewmaster Vaclav!
Brewmaster Vaclav Berka has the most important job this afternoon: he has to check the beer #NaZdravi Brewmaster Vaclav Berka
Brewmaster Vaclav Berka has the best job in the world: he gets to taste the beer every day! #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

The greatest job in the world? Past brewmasters taste Pilsner Urquell every day to check it’s the best it can be!

http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/parallel-brewing Timeline Photos

With a table of different malts and hops, plus a classic Pilsner recipe to follow, six teams brewed six different Pilsner-style beers. But which one did Brewmaster Vaclav Berka judge to be the best?

http://youtu.be/bR9_ZcbeZBM Pilsner Urquel Brew Off Six teams each brewed a Pilsner-style beer under the guidance of Brewmaster Vaclav Berka. Using a range of different ingredients, the teams created their own...

In May, Brewmaster Vaclav Berka taught six different teams how to brew their own versions of a Pilsner. Six weeks later they all returned to taste and judge their beers. But who brewed the best beer?

http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/brew-judging  Brew Off Judging Six teams and six different pilsners, but which was the best?

With sacks of malt and bags of hops, we’ve got six teams all competing to make the best pilsner they can, with help from our Brewmaster Vaclav Berka. It’s Brew Off! http://youtu.be/9enLcE1Oxs0 Pilsner Urquell Brew Off Who will make the best pilsner?

Perfect Pilsner Pour: Martina Navrátilová "I am the girl who understands beer better than some of the men sitting across the bar!”
If you're in Czech and you ask for a Pilsner, this is what you'll get. The perfect Pilsner pour is #BetterWithFoam Perfect Pilsner Pour: Hladinka

"I think the women softly care about the beer. We have more love. The man pours it harder." Veronika teaches people to pour perfect Pilsners and she notices the small differences in how they do it. Here's her story...

pilsnerurquell.com/article/perfect-pilsner-pour-veronika-mikésková Perfect Pilsner Pour: Veronika Mikésková
Now this is a perfect Pilsner pour, exactly as you get it in a Czech pub. Always demand that your Pilsner looks like this because it tastes better with foam #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

By brewing the #OriginalPilsner, Josef Groll became a legend in the beer world. But who was he?

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/josef-groll Timeline Photos
In 1842, Josef Groll travelled to Plzen where he changed beer forever #NaZdravi The Ingredients of Pilsner Urquell
#NaZdravi to Josef Groll and Vaclav Berka, the man who brewed the original pilsner in 1842 and the man who still makes it today Timeline Photos
From Josef Groll through to Vaclav Berka, our brewmasters pass the Pilsner Urquell recipe on with a simple message: Never change it Timeline Photos

In 1842 Josef Groll travelled to Plzen from his hometown of Vilshofen in Bavaria. It was a journey that would change beer forever when he brewed the world’s original golden lager.

A few months ago our German friends recreated Groll’s journey, meeting craftsmen along the way. This is Josef’s Way Josef's Way
Josef Groll came to Plzen in 1842 and, with four simple ingredients, he changed beer forever #NaZdravi The Ingredients of Pilsner Urquell

172 years ago, Josef Groll would’ve taken a candle down to the cellars when he was having the #FirstTaste of his new beer. Here's why we've always had a candle in the cellars... Pilsner Urquell Cellar Candle

171 years ago to this day our original brew master, Josef Groll,  brewed the first batch of a new golden larger, now known as Pilsner Urquell. Take a look at this specially designed Pilsner Urquell birthday cake Timeline Photos

World famous beer festival Oktoberfest starts tomorrow in Munich. Did you know Bavaria is where our original master brewer Josef Groll learnt his trade – he perfected his craft in Plzen to create the first golden Pilsner Timeline Photos

Today we're raising a glass to the original Pilsner brewer, Josef Groll, who was born 200 years ago today. Groll crafted the unique taste of the Pilsner Urquell we know and love today that continues to be brewed by our master brewer Vaclav Berka. Timeline Photos
This is important: Pilsner should be served in a cold, clean, wet glass. Demand the perfect pour #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

We talk about the perfect Pilsner pour because we want everyone to drink the beer when it's at its best. We make sure the beer is brewed perfectly, the rest happens when your Tapster pours it #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

“Most people come to Vienna for love. I came for the love of beer!” 

Brian Patton is making exciting things happen for beer in Vienna, with Tankovna Pilsner Urquell at the heart of his excellent pub, The Brickmakers Pub & Kitchen The Brickmakers, Vienna “That tanker drives 325km from Plzen to here. I know that and that means something to me. We’re in Vienna. Our neighbour is Czech.”
Drinking #Tankovna Pilsner Urquell? The beer is as fresh in your pub as it is in our brewery #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

Love Tankovna Pilsner Urquell? This beer is unpasteurised and delivered direct from the brewery to tanks in the pub, meaning it’s the freshest beer you can get outside of Plzen and the closest we can get to the experience of drinking in the brewery cellars. And soon you can get it installed in your home! #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

Tank Beer. Tankovna. The Pilsner Urquell in these is unpasteurised, it’s driven straight from Plzen to the pub, and it tastes as fresh from the tank as it does at the brewery #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

Our brewery cellars are naturally cool but during the summer months they weren’t quite cold enough, so we had to come up with a way to ensure a consistent year-round temperature. And that involved ice.  Here's the story:

http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/cooling-cellars Cooling the Cellars
Have you ever tasted the beer in the brewery cellars? Timeline Photos

There are 9km of cellars carved beneath the brewery. Come down and see why...

http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/brewery-cellars  The Brewery Cellars Stretching out over 9km in length, and sloping to depths of between 12-22m, the extensive network of cellars beneath the Pilsner Urquell brewery have played a key role in the history of the beer and the city.

Stretching out over 9km in length, and sloping to depths of between 12-22m, the extensive network of cellars beneath the Pilsner Urquell brewery have played a key role in the history of the beer and the city. You can find out all about them here: http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/brewery-cellars The Brewery Cellars

For over 170 years, a candle has been an important tool for the brewmasters in the brewery cellars... But why?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5757nePblyw 

http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/cellar-candle Pilsner Urquell's Cellar Candle Why was a candle always an important piece of equipment when going down into the brewery cellars? Our brewmasters will tell you more...
A Pilsner should have the perfect bittersweet balance of Czech hops and Pilsner malt. It should also glow bright gold in your glass #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
Czech Pilsner malt, Czech Saaz hops, Plzen’s soft water and our ‘H’ strain Czech yeast, all in perfect balance. A true Czech taste! #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
That bright golden colour? That's from the Pilsner malt we produce next to our brewhouse in Plzeň. The malt also gives the beer a soft caramel flavour #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
Bittersweet in the best way! Beautifully bitter Czech Saaz hops and sweet golden Pilsner malt #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
You can almost taste it, right? (You know: soft caramel from the Pilsner malt, those fragrant Saaz hops, the perfect bitter-sweet balance, that smooth foam…) #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
Soft Plzen water, barley turned into Pilsner malt in Plzen, Czech Saaz hops and our H-strain yeast. The recipe for the original golden lager #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
It's the malt that we produce ourselves in Plzen that gives the original Pilsner its bright, golden colour #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

This is Pilsner Malt. From Moravian fields to our malthouse to the brewery and then to your beer glass #OriginalPilsner

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/pilsner-malt Pilsner Malt (in 30 seconds)
We’ve always made our own malt in Plzen. It’s what gives the bright golden colour to the original Pilsner #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
It’s the malt which gives the original Pilsner its bright golden colour. Here’s how it goes from field to malthouse to brewery to beer glass #NaZdravi Pilsner Urquell's Barley
It’s called Pilsner Malt for a reason… #NaZdravi

In the brewhouse and it's time to check the wort (the sweet, golden liquid that results from the mix of Pilsner malt and Plzen's soft water). Next we'll transfer this into the brewing kettle and add the Czech Saaz hops Timeline Photos

A fine beer may be judged with only one sip, but it's better to be thoroughly sure - Czech Proverb

This month we will be launching a ‘Parallel Brewers’ challenge.  

Intrigued? 

Most of you will know that our Brew Master Václav regularly checks our beer against a sample batch of beer brewed using the original wooden barrels, to make sure it matches perfectly to the original brew. 

He’s going to be challenging you to try your own version of this unique technique…. barrels at the ready! 

If you are a budding home brewer then stay posted and we'll let you know more soon… Timeline Photos
First brewed on 5 October 1842, the original batch of Pilsner beer was presented to the people of Plzen on 11 November 1842, exactly 174 years ago today! #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

When we drank our Pilsner for the first time in 1842, we shared it with all the people in our hometown of Plzen. Today the beer is still brewed the same way, only now we get to share it with even more people #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
We call it Tankovna. We call it Tank Beer. We call it the freshest Pilsner in town #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

When Josef Groll took his beer to Plzen’s town square on 11 November 1842, he shared it with the whole town. Ever since that day, Pilsner has been a beer best shared with others #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

“Exclamations of awe were heard when its golden hue shone underneath the snow-white cap of froth; then the drinkers cheered its crisp, delicious taste, the likes of which they had never tasted before.” This is how the people of Plzen reacted to their first taste of the town’s new beer, which happened exactly 173 years ago today #NaZdravi Timeline Photos

This is how you announce you’re building a new brewery for your town in 1839

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/founding-document-pilsner-urquell Timeline Photos

With around 250 people having rights to brew, the people of Plzen made a big decision: they founded and funded a great new brewery for their town

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/community-founders Timeline Photos

What happened in the town of Plzen in the late 1830s to make the citizens decide to build their own brewery? 

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/plzen-pilsner-urquell Timeline Photos

Was Vaclav Mirwald the most influential man in creating a new town brewery for the citizens of Plzen?

For drinkers in other countries the appearance of the Hladinka – which has a lot of wet foam – might be a little surprising, but Czech lagers aren’t supposed to be poured the same way other beers... "English drinkers can complain about the foam and want their beer topped up. It’s a cultural thing. I just try to explain the importance of foam and flavour.” Meet Tapster Jacques from London’s The Duck & Rice. The Duck & Rice, London "I went to Plzeň on the Tapster Programme. It was there I realised how important the beer was. I came back with a burning mission to adapt my bar to be able to pour Pilsner Urquell properly."
Brilliant white foam, thick and smooth, with a neat line on top of the golden Pilsner. Beautiful beer perfection! #Betterwithfoam Timeline Photos

We told this Tapster that some drinkers outside of the Czech Republic want their Pilsner without foam. This was his reaction! #Betterwithfoam Timeline Photos

The thick foam on Pilsner Urquell is 'wet' foam. It's poured by the special Pilsner tap that we have and it works differently to the 'dry' foam on most other beers. Watch this Czech Hladinka pour and you'll see how the foam actually becomes beer. Foam is good. Pilsner Urquell tastes better with foam. Hladinka: Pilsner Urquell's classic Czech pour

It's unthinkable to serve a Pilsner without the foam in the Czech Republic. The Hladinka pour – or Smooth – is how we do it.

Here's the story: http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/classic-pilsner-pours-hladinka Drink it like a Czech. Have a Hladinka When you order a Pilsner, make sure you get a proper pour and drink it like we do.

Ever seen seven men rolling a 4,000 litre wooden beer barrel? 

The brewery coopers line the wooden barrels with pitch to stop the wood’s flavour imparting into the beer. When that barrel is enormous then it’s a big job for the team to ensure the whole of the inside of the barrel is covered in the pitch. And that means rolling it around their yard #NaZdravi Pitching the Beer Barrel

Meet Josef, Head Cooper, responsible for all the brewery's wooden barrels

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/people-pilsner-urquell-josef-hruza People of Pilsner Urquell: Josef Hruza What's it like to be a cooper at the brewery?
This was taken in 1900. Coopers have built and maintained wooden barrels at the brewery since 1842 – in fact, the processes have barely changed at all in that time Timeline Photos

Before stainless steel, beer was matured in and served from wooden barrels. Coopers made and maintained those barrels. At their peak in Plzen, we had over 250,000 small wooden barrels and 7,000 large ones, with 150 men working in the cooperage.

We still have a team of coopers at the brewery today. They still make small barrels and large ones for the beer that we still make and drink like we did decades ago. Here’s the coopers’ story http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/coopers-and-wooden-barrels Timeline Photos

Can you imagine a time when there were 7,000 large wooden barrels in our brewery cellars and the action in this video was a daily sight in the coopers’ yard?

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/large-wooden-barrels Building a Large Wooden Barrel

You can’t just cut down a tree and turn it into a wooden barrel. This is how our coopers choose the Czech oak for their barrels

http://pilsnerurquell.com/article/selecting-perfect-wood-beer-barrel Selecting the perfect wood for a beer barrel
What do you get when you combine seven skilled Czech craftsmen, a lot of Czech oak and a month of hard work? Building a Barrel in Seven Steps

The coopers’ yard in 1928. Each of these wooden barrels held over 2,000 litres of Pilsner Urquell and was built and maintained by hand. We still employ coopers today and they still build those big barrels by hand. Timeline Photos
Using Czech oak, built by hand, and filled with beer, wooden barrels are the heart of our brewery #NaZdravi Pilsner Urquell: Barrels and Brewing

How do we re-pitch the huge wooden barrels from the brewery cellars? Just like this!

http://youtu.be/Kr7GqFAjV0U
http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/pitching-barrels Pilsner Urquell: The Pitching of the Barrels Have you ever seen five guys rolling a giant oak beer barrel? Twice a year the coopers at Pilsner Urquell re-pitch and roll the barrels ready for fresh beer....

Twice a year our coopers remove the large wooden barrels from the brewery cellar and then re-pitch and roll them.

Pitch is made from tree resin which is heated to 200°C. This is then added to the inside of the barrel – we do this to ensure the beer doesn’t come into contact with the liquid and thereby changing the flavour of the beer.

But with such large barrels and such high temperatures, the process involves the coopers working together to roll the wooden vessels to get an even spread of the pitch.

Want to know more about the process and why we do it? Read it here: http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/pitching-barrels

Or see the video of the whole amazing process: http://youtu.be/Kr7GqFAjV0U Pitching the Barrels

For hundreds of years, wood was the material in which beer was universally stored and served from. It was the job of the coopers to make and maintain the barrels needed in breweries. By the 1970s, stainless steel kegs began to replace wooden casks, yet at Pilsner Urquell we've continually employed coopers for over 170 years and continue to mature and serve some of our beer from these wooden barrels. Here's some images of the coopers from past and present.

Have a look at this video of the barrels and the barrel makers: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k6GtHMDFvbs

And read more about the coopers here: http://pilsnerurquell.com/uk/article/coopers-and-wooden-barrels The Pilsner Urquell Coopers

“The Tapsters really make the pub – my customers come for their exceptional service and the way they look after the beer. It’s not an easy beer either, it can taste different in different bars but some people don’t care. My customers do. We now serve one of the best beers in Prague.” Na Hradčanské, Prague “The secret to a good bar is simple. Serve good beer and serve good food. Together it creates a great atmosphere."

Being a Štamgast is like being a bar's 'regular' only much more important. Here's what it means in the Czech Republic… Czech Pub Culture: The Štamgast Štamgast is a title bestowed in Czech pubs to only the most faithful regulars, the people who have been coming to the same pub for years

"People have a high expectation when they come here. We can’t disappoint them. People know this place for the beer quality.” U Bláhovky, Brno This is U Bláhovky, a small Brno bar with a huge reputation for excellent Pilsner Urquell
For 174 years, U Pinkasu has been serving Pilsner Urquell in Prague. It's a pub with perfect Pilsner, great Tapsters and a brilliant back story. Perfect Beer and Prague History in U Pinkasů

If our Brewmaster is a štamgast in your pub then you must be doing something right. Here’s what makes Prague's Konvikt great. Konvikt, Prague “I can’t explain why one bar is famous for its beer while others aren’t. We look after all the little details, so our pub has a different feeling to others. And when you do that, people will find you.”

“The name of the pub means ‘squirrel’ in Czech but we also use the word when we’re toasting each other here, indicating the squirrel’s tail. It’s slang for cheers. It’s become a bit of a tradition here.” U Veverky, Prague

'Authentic' is an over-used word but when the štamgast have been here for three decades, and the waitress started working here long before that, then you know there's something special about a place. This is Prague's U Jelínků, the bar where time stood still. U Jelínků, Prague The bar that still has the kind of atmosphere you can’t find anywhere else in Prague; an atmosphere of old, enjoyed today.

Why should you visit Na Hradčanské? Because the beer's so good it's where Prague's Tapsters go to drink #NaZdravi Na Hradčanské, Prague “The Tapsters really make the pub–my customers come for their exceptional service and the way they look after the beer. It’s not an easy beer either, it can taste different in different bars but some people don’t care. My customers do care."

“We want people to have an adventure – something they’ve never done before… You can’t find another place like it in Berlin.”

This is Birgit&Bier. Birgit und Bier, Berlin This is a new kind of biergarten, the type that can only be found in Berlin.

"It’s difficult to drink beer anywhere else because here it is perfect – the best!"

It's Ota's job to ensure that every beer at U Pinkasů *is* the best. Here’s what that means to him in the Prague pub that’s been serving Pilsner Urquell since 1843 Perfect Beer and Prague History in U Pinkasů “It’s my mission to make beer the same everywhere as it is in U Pinkasů,” he says. “It doesn’t matter who is the guest, it has to be perfect. The brewery in Plzen was originally built to make beer for the town. When that beer was ready, it was put into barrels and then loaded onto carts pulled by horses and delivered to the local taverns. Even though the horses were eventually replaced, that old method of delivery is one of those important traditions that we’ve kept going in Plzen and we continue to load a cart a few days a week to take beer to a few of the prominent local pubs, as well as stopping at some of the main sights in the city. So meet Jana Micova, the cart driver, and her two horses: Barna and Byka, both eight-year-old fillies, as they deliver beer in Plzen. Horse and Cart Beer Deliveries in Plzen

111 years ago Pope Leo XIII requested some Pilsner Urquell. A batch of beer was blessed and sent to him and since then we’ve often sent beer on the same journey.

Today the beer was blessed by Frantisek Radkovsky, Bishop of Plzen, during a sending-off ceremony at the brewery. Soon 2014 bottles – it's always the number of bottles as the year we’re in – will be going to the Vatican. Timeline Photos

“I’ve learnt you need to ensure four things are correct: temperature, pressure, cleanliness and service. If even one part isn’t precise, then it all breaks down.” Prazdroj, Bratislava At Prazdroj in Bratislava you can guarantee one of the finest, freshest glasses of Pilsner Urquell because everything from the beer to the tap are perfectly calibrated to ensure a perfect pour.
Take a closer look at your beer… Has the Tapster left their signature? The Tapster's Signature

At The Golden Tiger, the Tapster just pours. He barely even looks at the beer he’s pouring. It is said a good Tapster “feels their beer”. The Tapsters in this pub are some of the best there are. U Zlatého Tygra, Prague This is a Czech bar for Czech beer lovers. So grab a seat, if you can find one, settle in and enjoy an atmosphere as good as the Pilsner Urquell

"Not everyone can be a Tapster – people need time to become good and not everyone has the patience.” Michal clearly has what it takes as he’s been a Tapster for 17 years! Kolkovna, Prague "At Kolkovna we pride ourselves on our beer. Our customers drink five or six 50 litre kegs a day. We can’t get tank beer in this building so we serve the best keg beer we can."

But what have wet hands got to do with a perfectly poured Pilsner? Veronika will tell you...

“Anyone can learn to be a Tapster but a Tapster can’t be anyone. You need passion and love,” says Klára, Tapster at Brno’s Lokál. Timeline Photos

What creates the perfect glass of Pilsner Urquell? For Honza at U Bláhovky it’s the combination of brewery, Tapster and customer – the drinker has to demand the best to get the best #NaZdravi Timeline Photos
You walk into a pub. What’s one of the easiest ways to see if you’re going to get a good glass of beer? The Beermaster will tell you… How to tell if you'll get a perfectly-poured beer...

The Beer Master trains all the Pilsner Urquell Tapsters. That means beer lovers can taste the best beer possible.”

“The two most important people in a Czech pub are the Tapster and the chef, which is why I want to be a Tapster forever,” says Tomáš, the man who pours 1,000 beers a day at Lokál U Bílé Kuželky, Prague Lokál U Bílé Kuželky, Prague “I love it when people come up to me and say, ‘this is the perfect beer.’ It gives me the most pleasure and is the reason why I do what I do.”

Na Spilce is the largest restaurant in the Czech Republic. And it’s underneath our brewery. Come five metres underground and have a look around. Na Spilce, Plzen And did you know Na Spilce is in part of our old fermentation cellars?
Going over photos from a few weeks ago, enjoyable lunch and tour.

In Manchester, via Bavaria and Bohemia, is a ‘cook haus and bier palace' and the bar which pours the highest volume of tank Pilsner Urquell outside of the Czech Republic. This is the inimitable Alberts Schloss Albert’s Schloss, Manchester “Albert’s Schloss wants people to have fun. The atmosphere is incredible.”

“The future is very exciting. I’m trying to spread beer culture – focusing on quality first.”  

This is Adam Vlček, owner of Francis - Brewhemian Beer Café. In Plzeň he’s pouring great Pilsner Urquell alongside some of the best beers from small breweries around the Czech Republic. Francis Brewhemian Beer Café, Plzeň “My great-grandfather Alexandr worked at Pilsner Urquell... I have a portrait of Alexandr in my bar to remind me of the beer quality my family have always strived for.”

“Everything around you is either from the brewery or designed to look like it is. I took thousands of photos so I could recreate them perfectly to give my bar an atmosphere just like the brewery.”

This is Prazdroj, in Bratislava, the first Tankovna pub outside of the Czech Republic Prazdroj, Bratislava “It’s not my job, it’s my hobby,” says Mr Murčo. “You must do this with your heart. And I’ve never once compromised on quality in 16 years.”

Today we toured the historic and famous Pilsner Urquell brewery in Plzen. 

At the end of the tour we enjoyed a beer, in the bowels of the brewery, where the fermentation process finishes. It's an old school series of tunnels and passage ways stretching over 9km. Easily one of the most interesting places we've enjoyed a beer. 

Where is the most interesting place you've enjoyed a brew?

Here in Plzen we’ve been using the same yeast to make our beer since 1842, so it’s fascinating to read this great story in The New York Times about microbiologists and brewers looking into the DNA of beer yeast. And did you know that yeasts can produce over 500 different aromas and flavours? 

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/27/science/craft-beer-at-the-genetic-level.html 
 Strange Brews: The Genes of Craft Beer While brewing yeast is one of the best-studied organisms in molecular and cell biology, exactly how its genes translate to varied beers is still poorly understood.

Hi everyone! This is Mark Dredge and I’m Pilsner Urquell’s Beer Correspondent. It’s my job to tell the many great stories and happenings at the brewery and to talk with you about beer (before you ask: yes, my mates are all jealous that I’ve got the best job in the world). When I’m not here, I write a beer blog, I love to travel to drink the best beers I can find, and I’ve also written two books about beer: Craft Beer World and Beer & Food. I’ve already been working on some exciting stories from the brewery and I’m looking forward to sharing them with you.
